FREN 785: Decolonizing French
Xavier, W 1:00-4:00pm
 
Content: What does decolonization mean to the study of French today? How might one pursue a decolonial approach to the analysis of literature through a politics of reparations and an ethics rooted in freedom? This course will consider literary texts by some of the most important writers of the 20th and 21st century who made it their explicit aim to decolonize French, as language, culture and most importantly, cognitive empire. Works studied will include poetry and prose accompanied by selected readings in decolonial theory.
Particulars:  In French. Students with good reading knowledge and communication skills in French are encouraged to enroll and can deliver their presentation and write papers in English.
Texts: 
Léon Gontran Damas, Black-Label (1956)
Tchicaya U Tamsi, Le Ventre (1964)
Ahmadou Kourouma, Le soleil des indépendances (1968)
Véronique Tadjo, Latérite (1984)
Assia Djebar, Loin de Médine (1991)
Natasha Kanape Fontaine, N'entre pas dans mon âme avec tes chaussures (2012)
